metadata.title: Shark Bay Context Graph Analysis
metadata.methodology: Market-price valuation with propagated CIs (blue carbon focus)
metadata.disclaimer: This is a methodology demonstration, not investment advice

carbon_sequestration_rate.note: Rate from Mazarrasa et al. 2025 global seagrass estimates

carbon_stock.note: Up to 1.3% of global seagrass sediment carbon stored in top metre

financial_output.valuation_method_note: Carbon valued via voluntary carbon credit pricing ($15-50/tCO2); fisheries and tourism via market-price expenditure

climate_resilience.heatwave_exposure: High - 2010/2011 marine heatwave elevated temperatures 2-4C above average for >2 months
climate_resilience.recovery_status: Partial - seagrass recovery ongoing but incomplete after >15 years

degradation_risk.note: 2-9 Tg CO2 potentially released following the 2010/2011 heatwave, increasing Australia land-use-change emissions by 4-21% per annum

comparison_sites.name: Cabo Pulmo (Coral Reef)
comparison_sites.outcome: 463% biomass recovery; $29.27M ESV dominated by tourism ($25.0M)
comparison_sites.lesson: Coral reef sites are tourism-dominant. Shark Bay demonstrates that seagrass sites generate value primarily through carbon sequestration.

comparison_sites.name: Bahamas Seagrass (Caribbean)
comparison_sites.outcome: 92,000 km2 seagrass extent; carbon stock estimates emerging but limited market integration
comparison_sites.lesson: Larger seagrass systems may store more carbon but lack the governance and market infrastructure for monetization.

prepare.recommendation: Maintain NEOLI alignment, develop blue carbon credit methodology under VM0033, establish permanence monitoring

verra_vcs.methodology: VM0033 - Methodology for Tidal Wetland and Seagrass Restoration v2.1
verra_vcs.applicability: Seagrass conservation and restoration within the World Heritage Area
verra_vcs.note: Seagrass projects remain rare in VCM; only ~10 blue carbon projects actively issuing credits globally as of 2025

bridge_axioms_applied.name: seagrass_carbon_sequestration_rate
bridge_axioms_applied.application: Carbon sequestration valuation - 0.84 tCO2/ha/yr across 4,800 km2

bridge_axioms_applied.name: blue_carbon_credit_valuation
bridge_axioms_applied.application: Carbon credit pricing at $15-50/tCO2 under voluntary market standards

bridge_axioms_applied.name: seagrass_carbon_reversal_risk
bridge_axioms_applied.application: Carbon release quantification from 2010/2011 heatwave - 2-9 Tg CO2

bridge_axioms_applied.name: mpa_carbon_permanence_guarantee
bridge_axioms_applied.application: NEOLI 4+/5 provides permanence framework for carbon credit eligibility

caveats: Carbon credit pricing uses a $15-50/tCO2 range reflecting 2025-2026 voluntary market conditions; actual prices vary by project quality, verification standard, and buyer demand
Seagrass carbon sequestration rates vary by species composition, sediment type, and water quality - the 0.84 tCO2/ha/yr rate is a global mean
The 2010/2011 marine heatwave demonstrated that seagrass carbon stocks are vulnerable to climate-driven reversal events, which directly impacts permanence guarantees required for carbon credits
Market assumptions are based on voluntary carbon market data; compliance market integration could significantly alter pricing but remains uncertain for blue carbon
This is a methodology demonstration, not investment advice. Independent audit recommended before any investment decisions
